doc.abstracts: On February 10, 1993, Lewis Thompson Preston was interviewed by the Brookings Institution on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by John Lewis, Richard Webb, and Devesh Kapur. During his tenure at the Bank from 1991 to 1995, Mr. Preston served as the eighth president of the World Bank Group. He is known for creating a client-oriented vision for the Bank as it celebrated its 50th anniversary. His transcript concerns institutional change. During his presidency, Mr. Preston saw occur many events of significance to the World Bank: the admission of the republics of the former Soviet Union to Bank membership, the initiation of lending programs in the newly democratic South Africa, the resumption of lending operations in Vietnam, the influx of private sector capital into developing countries, the criticisms of the non-governmental organizations, the Wapenhans Report on Portfolio Management, the Morse Commission report on Sardar Sarovar, the Main Complex Rehabilitation Project, the Business Innovation and Simplification (BIAS) Committee, the establishment of the Inspection Panel, and the establishment of operational policies to ensure the protection of indigenous peoples and environmental safeguards.
